fr:ul.fr:li: A splitting C \cong D \oplus E, where E is a split exact.
A chain homotopy h : C \to C satisfying h \circ h = 0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = h.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Substituting the requirement that h is a homotopy \textrm {id} \to g \circ f, we get the equation d_{k+1} \circ r_k + r_{k-1} \circ d_k = \textrm {id} , where d is the boundary operator on E_ \bullet. In other words, r is a null-homotopy of E_ \bullet, rendering it split exact. Conversely, given C \cong D \oplus E, we can reconstruct f and g as the projection and inclusion maps, with h obtained out of r in the manner depicted above.

Finally, restricting h onto D_k we see that it must be zero, since h( \textrm {id} - p) = h - h \circ d \circ h = 0. This means that all the information of h can be reconstructed from the splitting, and thus all three sets of data are equivalent.
